when_to_say: When greeting someone casually.
example: Merhaba! Nasılsın? (Hello! How are you?)

when_to_say: When greeting someone in the morning.
example: Günaydın! Bugün hava güzel. (Good morning! The weather is nice today.)

when_to_say: When greeting or parting in the afternoon.
example: İyi günler dilerim! (I wish you a good day!)

when_to_say: When greeting or parting in the evening.
example: İyi akşamlar! Görüşürüz. (Good evening! See you later.)

when_to_say: When leaving someone and saying goodbye.
example: Hoşça kal! Yarın görüşürüz. (Goodbye! See you tomorrow.)

when_to_say: When expressing gratitude.
example: Teşekkür ederim! Yardımınız için. (Thank you! For your help.)

when_to_say: When politely requesting something.
example: Lütfen kapıyı açar mısınız? (Please open the door.)

when_to_say: When affirming or agreeing.
example: Evet, bu doğru. (Yes, that is correct.)

when_to_say: When denying or disagreeing.
example: Hayır, bunu istemiyorum. (No, I don't want this.)

when_to_say: When apologizing.
example: Özür dilerim, geç kaldım. (I'm sorry, I'm late.)

when_to_say: When talking about romantic feelings.
example: Aşk, hayatı güzelleştirir. (Love makes life beautiful.)

when_to_say: When referring to a companion.
example: Bu benim arkadaşım Ali. (This is my friend Ali.)

when_to_say: When describing a joyful state.
example: Bugün çok mutluyum. (I am very happy today.)

when_to_say: When describing a sorrowful state.
example: O bugün çok üzgün. (She is very sad today.)

when_to_say: When describing something aesthetically pleasing.
example: Manzara çok güzel. (The view is very beautiful.)

when_to_say: When describing something unattractive.
example: Bu tablo çok çirkin. (This painting is very ugly.)

when_to_say: When describing the large size of something.
example: Bu ev çok büyük. (This house is very big.)

when_to_say: When describing the small size of something.
example: Küçük bir hediye aldım. (I got a small gift.)

when_to_say: When describing something positive.
example: Bugün hava çok iyi. (The weather is very good today.)

when_to_say: When describing something negative.
example: Bu film kötüydü. (This movie was bad.)

when_to_say: When describing something that moves quickly.
example: Araba çok hızlı gidiyor. (The car is going very fast.)

when_to_say: When describing something that moves slowly.
example: Lütfen yavaş konuş. (Please speak slowly.)

when_to_say: When referring to the cooking area in a home.
example: Mutfakta yemek yapıyorum. (I am cooking in the kitchen.)

when_to_say: When referring to the bathroom.
example: Banyo temiz mi? (Is the bathroom clean?)

when_to_say: When referring to the main room in a home.
example: Oturma odasında televizyon izliyoruz. (We are watching TV in the living room.)

when_to_say: When referring to the sleeping room.
example: Yatak odasında kitap okuyorum. (I am reading a book in the bedroom.)

when_to_say: When referring to the garden area.
example: Bahçede çiçekler var. (There are flowers in the garden.)

when_to_say: When referring to an entryway.
example: Kapıyı kapatır mısınız? (Can you close the door?)

when_to_say: When referring to a glass opening in a wall.
example: Pencereyi açabilir misin? (Can you open the window?)

when_to_say: When referring to a table.
example: Masada kitap var. (There is a book on the table.)

when_to_say: When referring to a chair.
example: Sandalyeyi masanın yanına koy. (Put the chair next to the table.)

when_to_say: When referring to a place for sleeping.
example: Yatağımı sabah topladım. (I made my bed in the morning.)

when_to_say: When referring to a sofa or armchair.
example: Koltuk çok rahat. (The sofa is very comfortable.)

when_to_say: When referring to a carpet or rug.
example: Halıyı temizlemek gerekiyor. (The carpet needs cleaning.)

when_to_say: When referring to a reflective surface.
example: Aynada kendime baktım. (I looked at myself in the mirror.)

when_to_say: When referring to a light source.
example: Lamba bozulmuş. (The lamp is broken.)

when_to_say: When referring to a book.
example: Bu kitap çok ilginç. (This book is very interesting.)

when_to_say: When referring to a notebook.
example: Defterime not alıyorum. (I am taking notes in my notebook.)

when_to_say: When referring to a pen.
example: Kalemim kırıldı. (My pen broke.)

when_to_say: When referring to an eraser.
example: Silgiyi masadan alabilir misin? (Can you take the eraser from the table?)

when_to_say: When referring to a computer.
example: Bilgisayarım bozuldu. (My computer is broken.)

when_to_say: When referring to a telephone or smartphone.
example: Telefonum çalıyor. (My phone is ringing.)

when_to_say: When referring to time or a clock.
example: Saat kaçı gösteriyor? (What time does the clock show?)

when_to_say: When referring to an automobile.
example: Yeni bir araba aldık. (We bought a new car.)

when_to_say: When referring to a bicycle.
example: Bisikletle sahile gittim. (I went to the beach by bicycle.)

when_to_say: When referring to a train.
example: Tren saat kaçta kalkıyor? (What time does the train leave?)

when_to_say: When referring to an airplane.
example: Uçak çok hızlıdır. (The airplane is very fast.)

when_to_say: When referring to a ship or large boat.
example: Gemiyle adaya gittik. (We went to the island by ship.)

when_to_say: When referring to a group of people.
example: Pazar yeri çok kalabalıktı. (The marketplace was very crowded.)

when_to_say: When describing something that is empty.
example: Bardak boş. (The glass is empty.)

when_to_say: When referring to a storage unit.
example: Dolapta süt var mı? (Is there milk in the cupboard?)

when_to_say: When referring to a place where books are kept.
example: Kütüphanede ders çalışıyorum. (I am studying at the library.)

when_to_say: When referring to a road or street.
example: Sokakta çocuklar oynuyor. (Children are playing on the street.)

when_to_say: When referring to a road or path.
example: Yol çok uzundu. (The road was very long.)

when_to_say: When referring to a public park.
example: Parkta yürüyüş yaptık. (We took a walk in the park.)

when_to_say: When referring to an educational institution.
example: Okul sabah sekizde başlıyor. (School starts at 8 AM.)

when_to_say: When referring to a university.
example: Üniversite sınavına hazırlanıyorum. (I am preparing for the university exam.)

when_to_say: When discussing the weather.
example: Hava bugün çok güzel. (The weather is very nice today.)

when_to_say: When referring to the sun.
example: Güneş doğuyor. (The sun is rising.)

when_to_say: When referring to the moon.
example: Ay bu gece çok parlak. (The moon is very bright tonight.)

when_to_say: When referring to stars in the sky.
example: Gece gökyüzünde yıldızlar çok güzel. (The stars are beautiful in the night sky.)

when_to_say: When referring to clouds.
example: Gökyüzü bulutlu. (The sky is cloudy.)

when_to_say: When referring to rain.
example: Yağmur yağıyor. (It is raining.)

when_to_say: When referring to snow.
example: Dağlarda kar var. (There is snow on the mountains.)

when_to_say: When referring to wind.
example: Bugün çok rüzgarlı. (It is very windy today.)

when_to_say: When referring to a mountain.
example: Dağa tırmanıyoruz. (We are climbing the mountain.)

when_to_say: When referring to the sea.
example: Denizde yüzmeyi seviyorum. (I love swimming in the sea.)

when_to_say: When referring to a river.
example: Nehir boyunca yürüdük. (We walked along the river.)

when_to_say: When referring to a forest.
example: Ormanda kamp yaptık. (We camped in the forest.)

when_to_say: When referring to flowers.
example: Bahçede çiçekler açmış. (Flowers have bloomed in the garden.)

when_to_say: When referring to trees.
example: Ağaçlar gölgelik yapar. (Trees provide shade.)

when_to_say: When referring to fruits.
example: Meyve salatası yaptım. (I made a fruit salad.)

when_to_say: When referring to vegetables.
example: Sebzeleri doğrayabilir misin? (Can you chop the vegetables?)

when_to_say: When referring to apples.
example: Elma yemek sağlıklıdır. (Eating apples is healthy.)

when_to_say: When referring to bananas.
example: Kahvaltıda muz yedim. (I ate a banana for breakfast.)

when_to_say: When referring to strawberries.
example: Çilek reçeli yaptım. (I made strawberry jam.)

when_to_say: When referring to tomatoes.
example: Salataya domates ekledim. (I added tomatoes to the salad.)

when_to_say: When referring to potatoes.
example: Patates kızartması yaptık. (We made french fries.)

when_to_say: When referring to carrots.
example: Havuç çorbası yapmayı denedim. (I tried making carrot soup.)

when_to_say: When referring to onions.
example: Soğan doğramayı öğreniyorum. (I am learning to chop onions.)

when_to_say: When referring to garlic.
example: Sarımsak yemeklere lezzet katar. (Garlic adds flavor to dishes.)

when_to_say: When referring to bread.
example: Sabah kahvaltısında ekmek yedim. (I ate bread for breakfast.)

when_to_say: When referring to cheese.
example: Kahvaltıda peynir çok seviyorum. (I love cheese for breakfast.)

when_to_say: When referring to milk.
example: Süt kahvaltının önemli bir parçasıdır. (Milk is an important part of breakfast.)

when_to_say: When referring to yogurt.
example: Yoğurt sağlıklı bir yiyecektir. (Yogurt is a healthy food.)

when_to_say: When referring to honey.
example: Bal tatlı ve doğal bir besindir. (Honey is a sweet and natural food.)

when_to_say: When referring to eggs.
example: Sabah kahvaltısında yumurta yiyorum. (I eat eggs for breakfast.)

when_to_say: When referring to meat.
example: Et yemeklerinin tadı harika. (Meat dishes taste amazing.)

when_to_say: When referring to chicken.
example: Bu akşam tavuk pişireceğim. (I will cook chicken tonight.)

when_to_say: When referring to fish.
example: Balık sağlıklı bir yiyecektir. (Fish is a healthy food.)

when_to_say: When referring to soup.
example: Kışın çorba içmeyi seviyorum. (I love drinking soup in winter.)

when_to_say: When referring to cooked rice.
example: Pilav yapmayı öğreniyorum. (I am learning to make rice.)

when_to_say: When referring to pasta.
example: Makarna çok lezzetliydi. (The pasta was very delicious.)

when_to_say: When referring to salad.
example: Salatayı limonla severim. (I like salad with lemon.)

when_to_say: When referring to sugar.
example: Çaya biraz şeker ekledim. (I added some sugar to the tea.)

when_to_say: When referring to salt.
example: Yemeğe tuz koymayı unuttum. (I forgot to add salt to the food.)

when_to_say: When referring to pepper.
example: Biberler çok acıydı. (The peppers were very spicy.)

when_to_say: When referring to oil.
example: Yemek pişirirken biraz yağ ekledim. (I added some oil while cooking.)

when_to_say: When referring to coffee.
example: Sabah kahvesiz uyanamam. (I can't wake up without coffee in the morning.)

when_to_say: When referring to tea.
example: Türk çayı çok meşhurdur. (Turkish tea is very famous.)

when_to_say: When referring to water.
example: Bir bardak su rica ederim. (I would like a glass of water.)

when_to_say: When referring to fruit juice.
example: Kahvaltıda meyve suyu içtim. (I drank juice for breakfast.)

when_to_say: When referring to lemonade.
example: Sıcak günlerde limonata içerim. (I drink lemonade on hot days.)

when_to_say: When referring to soda.
example: Gazozu çok seviyorum. (I love soda.)

when_to_say: When referring to ice cream.
example: Dondurma sıcak yaz günlerinde harikadır. (Ice cream is great on hot summer days.)

when_to_say: When referring to sweet dishes or desserts.
example: Tatlı yemekten sonra servis edilir. (Dessert is served after a meal.)

when_to_say: When referring to chocolate.
example: Çikolata çok lezzetli bir atıştırmalıktır. (Chocolate is a very delicious snack.)

when_to_say: When referring to cake.
example: Doğum gününde pasta kestik. (We cut a cake for the birthday.)

when_to_say: When referring to cookies.
example: Kurabiye çayın yanında harikadır. (Cookies are great with tea.)

when_to_say: When talking about family members collectively.
example: Aile, hayattaki en önemli şeydir. (Family is the most important thing in life.)

when_to_say: When referring to your mother.
example: Anne yemek yapıyor. (Mom is cooking.)

when_to_say: When referring to your father.
example: Babam işe gitti. (My father went to work.)

when_to_say: When referring to your brother or sister.
example: Kardeşim okulda. (My sibling is at school.)

when_to_say: When referring to your older brother.
example: Abim kitap okuyor. (My older brother is reading a book.)

when_to_say: When referring to your older sister.
example: Ablam pasta yapıyor. (My older sister is making a cake.)

when_to_say: When referring to a young person.
example: Çocuklar parkta oynuyor. (The children are playing in the park.)

when_to_say: When referring to an infant.
example: Bebek çok sevimli. (The baby is very cute.)

when_to_say: When referring to your husband or wife.
example: Eşimle birlikte tatile gidiyoruz. (We are going on vacation with my spouse.)

when_to_say: When referring to a companion.
example: Arkadaşım beni ziyarete geldi. (My friend came to visit me.)

when_to_say: When referring to a neighbor.
example: Komşularımız çok nazik. (Our neighbors are very kind.)

meaning: concerned with or seeking to promote human welfare
when_to_say: When referring to actions or policies intended to benefit people in need.
example: The humanitarian aid was essential after the flood disaster.

meaning: assistance provided to help people in difficult situations
when_to_say: When talking about help provided to those in distress or need.
example: The relief workers provided food and water to the victims.

meaning: the desire to promote the welfare of others, expressed especially by the donation of money to good causes
when_to_say: When referring to charitable acts or donations made for the betterment of society.
example: Her philanthropy helped build schools for underprivileged children.

meaning: sympathetic pity and concern for the sufferings or misfortunes of others
when_to_say: When expressing a feeling of empathy or kindness towards someone in need.
example: He showed great compassion by donating to the flood victims.

meaning: unity or agreement of feeling or action, especially among individuals with a common interest
when_to_say: When referring to mutual support or unity in a cause.
example: The community showed solidarity by contributing to the relief fund.

meaning: the capacity to recover quickly from difficulties
when_to_say: When talking about the ability to overcome adversity or bounce back from challenges.
example: The resilience of the people after the disaster was inspiring.

meaning: the ability to understand and share the feelings of another
when_to_say: When expressing understanding and sharing someone else's emotional experience.
example: She showed great empathy towards the earthquake survivors.

meaning: a person who freely offers to take part in an enterprise or undertake a task
when_to_say: When referring to someone offering help or services without expecting payment.
example: The volunteers worked tirelessly to distribute food and aid.

meaning: the voluntary giving of help, typically in the form of money, to those in need
when_to_say: When talking about the act of giving to those less fortunate.
example: The charity event raised a significant amount for the flood victims.

meaning: a gift or payment to a common fund or cause
when_to_say: When talking about donating or giving towards a cause.
example: His contribution to the flood relief fund was greatly appreciated.

meaning: help, typically of a practical nature, provided to those in need
when_to_say: When referring to assistance provided to people in difficult situations.
example: The government sent aid to the flood victims immediately.

meaning: a series of organized activities or actions aimed at achieving a specific goal
when_to_say: When discussing a series of actions taken to promote or achieve a particular objective.
example: The charity launched a campaign to raise funds for the disaster victims.

meaning: a gift or contribution made to a person, organization, or cause
when_to_say: When referring to something given to help a cause or someone in need.
example: She made a generous donation to the relief fund.

meaning: a sudden event, such as an accident or a natural catastrophe, that causes great damage or loss of life
when_to_say: When referring to a sudden and catastrophic event, typically natural.
example: The hurricane was a disaster that left thousands homeless.

meaning: the process of returning to a normal state of health, mind, or strength
when_to_say: When referring to the process of regaining strength or normalcy after a crisis.
example: The city began its recovery after the earthquake, with rebuilding efforts underway.

meaning: a feeling of expectation and desire for a certain thing to happen
when_to_say: When expressing a positive expectation for the future.
example: The community's hope was restored after the relief arrived.

when_to_say: When something needs immediate action or attention.
example: The relief team responded to the urgent needs of the flood victims.

meaning: the quality of being thankful; readiness to show appreciation for and to return kindness
when_to_say: When expressing thanks or appreciation for something or someone.
example: The survivors expressed their gratitude for the aid they received.

meaning: the quality of being kind and generous
when_to_say: When talking about the act of being kind and giving to others.
example: His generosity knew no bounds, and he donated all his savings to the relief effort.

meaning: to give assistance or help to someone or something
when_to_say: When helping or assisting someone, typically in times of need.
example: The organization supported the victims of the disaster with food and supplies.

meaning: to give something, especially money, to a charity or cause
when_to_say: When giving or contributing to a cause or charity.
example: She decided to donate a portion of her salary to the disaster relief fund.

meaning: an event or activity organized to raise money for a particular cause
when_to_say: When referring to events or activities designed to raise money for a specific cause.
example: The school organized a fundraiser to collect donations for the disaster victims.

meaning: the use or involvement of volunteer labor, typically for charitable causes
when_to_say: When referring to the act of volunteering or offering services without compensation.
example: Her volunteerism during the relief effort inspired others to contribute.

meaning: the action of working with someone to produce or create something
when_to_say: When working together with others towards a common goal.
example: The collaboration between various NGOs helped speed up the relief process.

meaning: unity or agreement of feeling or action, especially among individuals with a common interest
when_to_say: When referring to mutual support or unity in a cause.
example: The international solidarity with the disaster-stricken areas was overwhelming.

meaning: to build something again after it has been damaged or destroyed
when_to_say: When discussing the act of constructing or repairing something after damage.
example: The town began to rebuild after the devastating earthquake.

meaning: to move to a new place, typically for safety or work
when_to_say: When referring to the act of moving to a new location, often due to necessity.
example: The residents had to relocate due to the rising floodwaters.

meaning: to support, nourish, or maintain over time
when_to_say: When talking about keeping something going or maintaining a condition.
example: The funds will help sustain the relief efforts for the long term.

meaning: the action of keeping someone or something safe from harm or danger
when_to_say: When talking about the act of defending or keeping something safe.
example: The humanitarian organizations provided protection to those displaced by the disaster.

meaning: feeling or inspiring optimism about a future event
when_to_say: When expressing a positive outlook or belief in future success.
example: Despite the challenges, the community remained hopeful about the recovery.

meaning: a person who continues to live after an event or experience that causes others to die or suffer
when_to_say: When referring to a person who has lived through a difficult or life-threatening event.
example: The survivors of the earthquake shared their stories of resilience.

when_to_say: when describing events or decisions of great significance
example: The momentous decision to move abroad changed their lives forever.

meaning: able to recover quickly from difficulties
when_to_say: when describing a person or object that bounces back or recovers from a difficult situation
example: Despite the hardships, she remained resilient and kept moving forward.

when_to_say: when considering or reflecting deeply on a matter
example: He sat quietly to contemplate the choices he had before him.

when_to_say: when describing clear, understandable speech or writing
example: The professor’s explanation was so lucid that everyone understood the complex topic.

when_to_say: when describing someone who is kind and charitable
example: Her benevolent nature led her to volunteer at the shelter every weekend.

meaning: clear, sharp, and direct in expression
when_to_say: when describing a comment or action that cuts through confusion
example: His incisive questions during the meeting helped clarify the issue immediately.

meaning: difficult to find, catch, or achieve
when_to_say: when describing something that is hard to grasp or understand
example: The solution to the puzzle was so elusive that no one could figure it out.

meaning: showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise
when_to_say: when describing someone who is extremely careful and precise
example: The artist was meticulous in painting every fine detail of the portrait.

meaning: showing strong feeling; forceful, passionate, or intense
when_to_say: when expressing strong emotions or opinions
example: She was vehement in her defense of her beliefs.

when_to_say: when describing an argument or reasoning that is strong and convincing
example: His cogent argument persuaded everyone to agree with his proposal.

meaning: based on observation or experience rather than theory
when_to_say: when describing something grounded in actual data or experience
example: The scientific method relies heavily on empirical data to form conclusions.

meaning: not securely held or in position; dangerously likely to fall or collapse
when_to_say: when describing a situation that is risky or unstable
example: The climbers found themselves in a precarious position on the mountain.

meaning: to agree or have the same opinion
when_to_say: when expressing agreement with someone’s opinion or action
example: I concur with your idea and believe we should proceed with the plan.

meaning: to place two things side by side to compare or contrast them
when_to_say: when comparing two different things to highlight their contrasts
example: The artist juxtaposed dark and light tones in the painting to create a striking contrast.

meaning: based on random choice or personal whim, rather than any reason or system
when_to_say: when referring to decisions or actions that are made without logical reason
example: The manager made an arbitrary decision to change the work schedule without consulting anyone.

when_to_say: when describing something that is widespread or common
example: Smartphones have become ubiquitous in modern society.

meaning: having mixed feelings or contradictory ideas about something or someone
when_to_say: when describing someone who has conflicting emotions about a decision or situation
example: He felt ambivalent about accepting the new job offer.

meaning: a change of the form or nature of a thing or person into a completely different one
when_to_say: when describing a complete transformation or change
example: The caterpillar undergoes a metamorphosis to become a butterfly.

meaning: to overwhelm with things or people to be dealt with
when_to_say: when overwhelmed with a large number of things or people
example: The city was inundated with tourists during the festival.

meaning: large or heavy and difficult to carry or handle
when_to_say: when describing something that is unwieldy or difficult to manage
example: The old, cumbersome machinery took up a lot of space in the factory.

meaning: extremely complex and difficult to follow
when_to_say: when describing something that is complicated or twisted in a way that is hard to understand
example: The plot of the movie was so convoluted that I had trouble keeping track of the story.

meaning: to make something better or more bearable
when_to_say: when describing an improvement or alleviation of a problem
example: The new policies were designed to ameliorate the living conditions of the poor.

when_to_say: when describing someone who is deceitful or dishonest
example: The politician's mendacious statements led to his downfall.

meaning: essentially different in kind; not allowing comparison
when_to_say: when describing things that are so different that they can't be compared directly
example: The two cultures were so disparate that they had trouble understanding each other.

meaning: dealing with things sensibly and realistically
when_to_say: when describing someone who is practical and focused on real-world results
example: His pragmatic approach to problem-solving made him a valuable team member.

when_to_say: when describing the act of thinking carefully or considering something in depth
example: I need time to cogitate on your suggestion before I make a decision.

when_to_say: when describing someone who is full of life and energy
example: Her effervescent personality made her the life of the party.

meaning: happening by chance or accident, often in a lucky way
when_to_say: when describing an event or situation that occurs unexpectedly, often with a positive outcome
example: It was a fortuitous meeting that led to a great business partnership.

meaning: to spread or distribute information widely
when_to_say: when referring to the act of spreading information or knowledge
example: The organization works to disseminate information about health and safety.

meaning: to repeal or do away with a law or agreement
when_to_say: when describing the cancellation or invalidation of a rule or law
example: The government decided to abrogate the outdated law.

meaning: lasting for a very short time
when_to_say: when describing something that is short-lived or fleeting
example: The beauty of the sunset was ephemeral, disappearing as quickly as it arrived.

meaning: having a stubborn or uncooperative attitude
when_to_say: when describing someone who resists authority or control
example: The recalcitrant student refused to follow the teacher’s instructions.

when_to_say: when describing something that is unclear or difficult to understand
example: His explanation was so nebulous that no one could understand his point.

when_to_say: when something is justified or reasonable based on circumstances
example: The protest was warranted given the unfair treatment they had received.

meaning: mental calmness, composure, and evenness of temper, especially in a difficult situation
when_to_say: when describing someone who remains calm and collected under pressure
example: She faced the challenges with remarkable equanimity.

meaning: having a ready insight into and understanding of things
when_to_say: when describing someone who is highly perceptive or insightful
example: The perspicacious detective immediately noticed the small but important detail.

meaning: showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise
when_to_say: when describing someone who is extremely careful and precise
example: The artist was meticulous in painting every fine detail of the portrait.

when_to_say: when describing someone who never gets tired or gives up
example: Her indefatigable spirit kept her going through the toughest times.

meaning: to clear someone of blame or wrongdoing
when_to_say: when someone is cleared of blame or suspicion
example: The evidence exonerated the suspect, proving his innocence.

when_to_say: when describing someone who is loud and outspoken
example: The vociferous protestors demanded change from the government.

meaning: showing concern or care for someone's well-being
when_to_say: when showing or expressing concern for others
example: She was solicitous about his health after he had been sick for days.

meaning: done without real interest, feeling, or effort
when_to_say: when describing something done with little enthusiasm or effort
example: His perfunctory response showed that he wasn’t really paying attention.

meaning: a universal remedy or solution for all problems
when_to_say: when referring to a supposed solution that can fix all problems
example: Many people believe that technology is a panacea for all societal issues.

meaning: respect and esteem due to a superior or elder
when_to_say: when showing respect or submission to someone in authority
example: He showed deference to his parents by always listening to their advice.

meaning: unwilling to change one's views or to agree about something
when_to_say: when describing someone who is stubborn or refuses to compromise
example: The intransigent leader refused to consider any other solutions.

meaning: showing smug or uncritical satisfaction with oneself or one's achievements
when_to_say: when someone is overly self-satisfied and unaware of potential risks
example: He became complacent after winning a few games and stopped practicing.

meaning: a perfect example of a particular quality or type
when_to_say: when describing something that represents a perfect example of a particular quality
example: She is the epitome of kindness and generosity.

when_to_say: when describing someone or something that is overly idealistic and impractical
example: His quixotic plan to save the world was doomed to fail.

meaning: to make someone or something look or feel younger, fresher, or more lively
when_to_say: when describing the act of restoring vitality or youthfulness
example: The spa treatments were designed to rejuvenate both body and mind.

meaning: clarity, being clear and easy to understand
when_to_say: when describing something that is clear and easily understood
example: The professor’s perspicuity made complex topics easy to grasp.

meaning: lasting only for a short time
when_to_say: when describing something that does not last for long
example: The transient beauty of the rainbow disappeared as quickly as it appeared.

when_to_say: when describing someone who is hardworking and diligent
example: Her assiduous work ethic earned her a promotion.

meaning: a person or thing that announces or signals the approach of another
when_to_say: when referring to something or someone that indicates what is to come
example: The robin is often seen as a harbinger of spring.

when_to_say: when describing something that cannot be changed or avoided
example: The inexorable rise of technology continues to reshape society.

when_to_say: when someone is deep in thought or reflecting
example: She had a pensive expression on her face as she stared out the window.

when_to_say: when describing something that is concise and to the point
example: His succinct explanation made it easy for everyone to understand.

when_to_say: when referring to someone’s physical beauty
example: Her pulchritude was admired by all who met her.

meaning: pretentious or juvenile; relating to or characteristic of a sophomore
when_to_say: when describing someone or something that is immature or overconfident in a foolish way
example: His sophomoric remarks showed that he still had a lot to learn.

meaning: occurring at irregular intervals; not continuous or steady
when_to_say: when describing something that stops and starts repeatedly
example: The intermittent rain made it difficult to plan outdoor activities.

when_to_say: when describing something that is harmful or toxic
example: The noxious fumes from the factory polluted the air.

when_to_say: when describing someone who enjoys being around people
example: He was a gregarious person who loved meeting new people.

meaning: the ability to make good judgments and quick decisions
when_to_say: when referring to someone’s sharp insight or judgment
example: Her business acumen helped her build a successful company.

meaning: extremely severe or harmful in its effects
when_to_say: when describing something that is harmful or dangerous in an extreme way
example: The virus was virulent and spread quickly across the region.

meaning: proceeding in a gradual, subtle way but with harmful effects
when_to_say: when describing something that develops gradually and secretly but is harmful
example: The insidious effects of smoking may not be immediately apparent.

when_to_say: when referring to a long, aggressive, and critical speech
example: The politician delivered a harangue on the evils of corruption.

meaning: reserved or uncommunicative in speech; saying little
when_to_say: when describing someone who is quiet or reluctant to talk
example: The taciturn man rarely spoke at the meetings.

meaning: to clear someone of blame or suspicion
when_to_say: when someone is proven to be innocent or justified
example: The new evidence will vindicate the accused man.

meaning: a harsh, discordant mixture of sounds
when_to_say: when describing a loud, jarring noise
example: The cacophony of car horns in the city was unbearable.

meaning: a feeling of fear or agitation about something that may happen
when_to_say: when referring to a feeling of anxiety or fear about something uncertain
example: She entered the room with trepidation, unsure of what to expect.

meaning: to make something better or more tolerable
when_to_say: when trying to improve or make a situation better
example: The government implemented new policies to ameliorate the economic crisis.

meaning: to mourn or express sorrow for something
when_to_say: when expressing sadness or sorrow about something
example: They lamented the loss of their beloved pet.

meaning: inactive, in a state of rest or sleep
when_to_say: when describing something that is temporarily inactive or not functioning
example: The volcano has been dormant for over a century.

meaning: to describe or portray something precisely
when_to_say: when describing something in a detailed and clear manner
example: The architect delineated the plans for the new building.

meaning: behaving or looking as though one thinks one is superior to others
when_to_say: when describing someone who is arrogantly superior
example: The supercilious manager looked down on his employees.

when_to_say: when referring to something that is persuasive and well-reasoned
example: His cogent argument won over even the skeptics.

meaning: a confusing and difficult problem or question
when_to_say: when describing a problem that is difficult to solve or understand
example: The puzzle was a conundrum that took hours to solve.

when_to_say: when describing a person or style that is brief and to the point
example: His laconic response left no room for further discussion.

when_to_say: when describing something that is bland or uninteresting
example: The soup was insipid and lacked any real flavor.

meaning: a mild or indirect word or expression substituted for one considered too harsh or blunt
when_to_say: when substituting a more polite or mild expression for something harsh
example: Saying 'passed away' instead of 'died' is a common euphemism.

when_to_say: when describing someone who is stubbornly disobedient or uncooperative
example: The recalcitrant student refused to follow the rules.

meaning: a tendency to choose or do something regularly
when_to_say: when describing someone's natural inclination or habit
example: He has a proclivity for procrastination.

meaning: to make something less severe, serious, or painful
when_to_say: when reducing the severity or intensity of something
example: The doctor gave her medication to mitigate the pain.

when_to_say: when describing someone who is angry or eager to argue or fight
example: The belligerent man started a fight at the bar.

meaning: lasting for a very short time
when_to_say: when referring to something that is fleeting or short-lived
example: The beauty of the sunset was ephemeral, lasting only a few minutes.

meaning: mental calmness, especially in difficult situations
when_to_say: when describing someone who is calm and composed under pressure
example: She faced the crisis with equanimity, remaining calm throughout.

when_to_say: when describing something with deep significance or impact
example: His profound thoughts on philosophy were admired by everyone.

meaning: to make something better or more tolerable
when_to_say: when describing actions to improve a situation
example: The new regulations aim to ameliorate air quality.

meaning: a direct contrast or opposite of something
when_to_say: when comparing two things that are opposites
example: Her calm demeanor was the antithesis of his frantic behavior.

when_to_say: when describing someone who is kind and generous
example: The benevolent woman donated a large sum to the charity.

when_to_say: when being aware of something
example: She was cognizant of the risks involved in the decision.

when_to_say: when describing someone with impractical ideas
example: His quixotic plan to change the world was met with skepticism.

meaning: experienced in the imagination through the feelings or actions of another person
when_to_say: when feeling or living something through another person
example: She felt a vicarious thrill watching her son win the race.

meaning: believing that people are motivated purely by self-interest; distrustful of human sincerity
when_to_say: when describing someone who is distrustful or skeptical about others' motives
example: He had a cynical view of politics, believing that no politician could be trusted.

when_to_say: when showing respect or admiration for something
example: The reverent silence in the church was a testament to the solemn occasion.

when_to_say: when describing something with deep impact
example: His profound knowledge of history impressed the scholars.

meaning: carried out with minimal effort or reflection
when_to_say: when describing something done in a routine or superficial manner
example: Her perfunctory response showed that she was not really interested in the topic.

meaning: the lowest point in a person's life or career
when_to_say: when referring to the lowest point of something
example: The company's bankruptcy marked the nadir of its financial troubles.

meaning: rich and luxurious in appearance or quality
when_to_say: when describing something lavish or wealthy
example: The opulent mansion featured marble floors and chandeliers.

meaning: to place two or more things side by side for comparison
when_to_say: when comparing two or more things by placing them next to each other
example: The artist juxtaposed bright colors with dark shadows to create contrast.
